citation.article-title: Legionella pneumophila serogroup Lansing 3 isolated from a patient with fatal pneumonia, and descriptions of L. pneumophila subsp. pneumophila subsp. nov., L. pneumophila subsp. fraseri subsp. nov., and L. pneumophila subsp. pascullei subsp. nov.

p.s: Description of Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila subsp. nov.
Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila (pneu. mo'phi. la; Greek noun pneumo, lung; Greek adjective, philos, loving; M.L. adjectives, pneumophila, lung loving)
Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila contains strains representing all currently recognized serogroups (1 through 14) other than serogroup Lansing 3.

DNAs from all strains of the subspecies are related to Philadelphia 1 (ATCC 33152), the type strain of the species and of the subspecies, at the species level (>70% optimal relatedness, <3% divergence in related sequences, >60% stringent relatedness).
DNA relatedness to other subspecies is below the species. level in at least one and usually at least two of the hybridization parameters above.
By enzyme typing, strains within the subspecies are related at a genetic distance of 0.32 and are separated form the other subspecies at a distance of approximately 0.52.
The G+C content is 39 to 41 mol%.
It has been isolated from human lung, sputum, and blood and from water and is the major causative agent of Legionnaires' disease and Pontiac fever.
The type strain Philadelphia 1, isolated from human lung tissue, has a G+C content of 39 mol% (7).
